channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Sand collapse kills girl at U.S. beach
item.description: A 9-year-old died at an Oregon beach when a hole she was digging in the sand caved in and buried her, authorities said.

item.title: Ferrer, Sharapova stunned in US Open
item.description: Fourth seed David Ferrer was sent crashing out of the US Open by Frenchman Gilles Simon, the biggest scalp to be taken so far during the final grand slam of the season.

item.title: First openly gay NFL player dropped
item.description: The St. Louis Rams announced Saturday that Michael Sam, who made history as the first openly gay player to be drafted into the NFL, has been waived and did not make the team's final 53-man roster.

item.title: Ukrainian plane crashes in Algeria
item.description: A Ukrainian cargo plane crashed shortly after takeoff in mountainous southeastern Algeria on Saturday morning, killing seven people who were aboard, Algerian state-run news agency Algerie Presse Service reported.

item.title: Beheadings in ISIS camp for children
item.description: Children are being indoctrinated into ISIS's barbaric system of justice, one young boy tells CNN.

item.title: What is Russia doing in Ukraine?
item.description: Russia's tactics in Ukraine are difficult to pin down: The Kremlin categorically denies Russian troops are fighting alongside rebels there, or that the sophisticated weaponry being used against Ukrainian government forces is supplied by Moscow.

item.title: Are atheists 'unelectable' in U.S.?
item.description: This fall, for the first time in U.S. history, an openly atheist candidate is running for Congress. James Woods is fighting an uphill battle as a Democrat seeking to represent the very Republican 5th Congressional District in Arizona.

item.title: Abuse scandal shocks nation to core
item.description: The sex abuse of hundreds of children has shocked a nation.

item.title: The man who hunted bin Laden
item.description: On Thursday in Tampa, U.S. Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel presided over a change of command ceremony during which Adm. William "Bill" McRaven handed over the reins of Special Operations Command to his successor, Gen. Joseph Votel.

item.title: An American's gateway to jihad
item.description: On Wednesday, a propaganda video appeared on the Internet featuring Moner Abu-Salha, the U.S. citizen from Florida who died conducting a suicide bomb attack in Syria for al Qaeda in May.

item.title: Shinzo Abe scores historic own goal
item.description: Here at an international gathering of Japan specialists currently underway in Ljubljana, Slovenia, the actions of Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe in honoring his country's war criminals have come in for sharp criticism.

item.title: Russia 'attacks east Ukraine airfield,' officials say
item.description: Ukrainian military officials accuse Russia of attacking their airfields as the battle for control of the eastern part of the country intensifies.

item.title: Ukraine troops dejected, tired
item.description: A few miles south of the town of Starobeshevo in eastern Ukraine, a group of men in uniform is slumped under a tree.

item.title: Ukraine: 'Point of no return' looms
item.description: The conflict in Ukraine is ratcheting up as Russian troops enter the country by the thousands.

item.title: 4 arrested in Manila airport bomb plot
item.description: Four men have been arrested after allegedly trying to detonate a bomb at Manila's international airport Monday, state-run media in the Philippines report.

item.title: Kenneth Bae sends message to U.S.
item.description: Three Americans detained in North Korea spoke out about their conditions Monday in an exclusive interview with CNN's Will Ripley.

item.title: Police, protesters battle in Islamabad
item.description: Protesters demanding the resignation of the Pakistani Prime Minister engaged in running battles with police near government offices in the capital Monday.

item.title: China: No open elections in HK
item.description: A commentary in a state-run Chinese newspaper dismisses Hong Kong democracy advocates as a "paper tiger."

item.title: China: Man kills 3, jumps off building
item.description: A man killed three people at a primary school in central China on Monday and then committed suicide by jumping off a building, state media reported.

item.title: Thai PM names military-heavy cabinet
item.description: Thailand's military leader and Prime Minister General Prayuth Chan-ocha has unveiled a new interim cabinet in which key ministries will be run by senior military figures.

item.title: Prison in Somalia attacked; 12 dead
item.description: Islamist rebels attacked a prison in Somalia on Sunday and were fought off by security guards, who killed eight of the rebels, Somali Security Ministry spokesman Mohamed Yusuf told CNN.

item.title: Lesotho PM alleges army coup attempt
item.description: After an apparent attempted military coup on Saturday, the people of the African nation of Lesotho are doing their best to return to every day life.

item.title: Missing cancer boy's parents arrested
item.description: The parents who pulled their cancer-stricken son from a British hospital and spurred an international search for the boy have been arrested, police said.

item.title: Quake hits northern California
item.description: A 3.4-magnitude earthquake rumbled through northern California early Sunday, the U.S. Geological Survey said.

item.title: J-Law targeted in nude photo scandal
item.description: In a major breach of privacy, a hacker leaked a series of pictures allegedly showing Jennifer Lawrence and other female celebrities in the nude.

item.title: Elvis Presley's last two jets for sale
item.description: Elvis Presley's last two jets, the "Lisa Marie" and "Hound Dog II," are for sale.

item.title: Stewart's return to NASCAR cut short
item.description: What started as a deeply emotional race for Tony Stewart ended prematurely when a blown tire cut short his return to NASCAR.

item.title: Race to rescue U.N. officials in Syria
item.description: Officials are still trying to secure the release of dozens of U.N. peacekeepers from Fiji who were taken captive by al Qaeda-linked rebels from Syria.

item.title: U.S. lawmakers demand ISIS strategy
item.description: Residents celebrate as Iraqi and volunteer forces enter Amerli, breaking a two-month siege of the town by militants from terror group ISIS.

item.title: Israel shoots down drone near Syria
item.description: Israel has shot down an unmanned aerial vehicle that entered Israeli airspace near the Syrian border, the Israel Defense Forces said Sunday.

item.title: What starts in winter and lasts 8 years?
item.description: It's largely devoid of human life, dark and viciously cold at times and frequently subject to dangerous levels of geological volatility -- the Arctic is surely the worst possible destination for an arts festival.

item.title: Floating snowflake world's coolest hotel?
item.description: The Krystall hotel will doubtless inspire a few gags about a frosty reception when it opens in December 2016, but once guests realize they're about to check in to a giant floating snowflake, it could just as easily melt hearts.

item.title: The world's most beautiful clocks
item.description: 12 of the world's most beautiful clocks

item.title: Sculptures as thin as a hair
item.description: Most flowers start as seeds planted in soil, but Wim Noorduin, currently a post-doc researcher at Harvard, prefers to craft bouquets using Barium carbonate and sodium metasilicate. The two chemicals are disolved in a glass beaker filled with water and as carbon dioxide seeps into the vessel it kickstarts a chemical reaction that creates a wonderland of micro-sculptures that are about the diameter of the human hair.

item.title: Trieste, the city of fashion
item.description: Nudging the border with Slovenia in Italy's far north-east, the mysteriously underrated city of Trieste is largely known for its stately, Habsburg-era architecture, exquisite coffee, and traditional regattas.

item.title: World's most stylish bookstores
item.description: Someday there may be a generation of kids who think bookstores are fictional creations found only in novels that come in the mail.

item.title: Mystique of abandoned palaces
item.description: Patrycja Makowska likes to give enigmatic names to the extraordinarily beautiful photographs she shoots of crumbling palaces.

item.title: Is architecture dead? Not in Venice
item.description: Their stare is blank and unblinking; they just stand there rigid and dumb. Passers-by look on bemused as a child attempts to clamber up one of their backs. It's no harm, they are after all just a pair of concrete cows, painted white with cute little black spots.

item.title: Opinion: Why Hong Kong worries China
item.description: China fears that democracy in Hong Kong could destabilize Communist Party rule in China.

item.title: Joan Rivers' condition 'serious'
item.description: The latest statement from Joan Rivers' daughter gave no new information about the comedian's condition three days after she was rushed to a New York hospital.

item.title: Beslan atrocity,10 years after
item.description: School atrocity showed the limits of Putin's power and, for many, his failings as a leader. Nick Paton Walsh reports.

item.title: In a room with a million cockroaches
item.description: I've eaten some unusual things on the road.

item.title: 15 funniest travel books ever written
item.description: We expect a lot from our travel writers.

item.title: Is this paradise with a conscience?
item.description: A resort on remote Sumba has one of the world's best surf breaks, but that's only the start of the superlatives.

item.title: Militia parties at empty U.S. embassy
item.description: Libyan militia members have turned the abandoned U.S. embassy in Tripoli into a swim club.

item.title: Opinion: Libyans paying price for Mideast divide
item.description: A New York Times article has reported that the United Arab Emirates and Egypt have launched airstrikes in Libya against militias, without coordinating with their ally, the United States of America.

item.title: Summer movies we loathed and loved
item.description: Was it the end of the world at the summer box office?

item.title: What does 'perfect' wine taste like?
item.description: Most people don't taste one "perfect" wine their whole lives; now you can taste 10 in one four-day tour.

item.title: The world's first 'unstealable' bike
item.description: Move along, bicycle thieves: if you want to steal it, you have to break it.

item.title: What North Korea wants world to see
item.description: Get a rare glimpse of a country that has deliberately locked itself away from the outside world.

item.title: CNN tours Kim Jong Un's waterpark
item.description: CNN's Will Ripley is given a rare look inside North Korea and tours Kim Jong Un's pet project, a waterpark.

item.title: Pro wrestling in the 'Hermit Kingdom'
item.description: CNN's Will Ripley gets a rare look at a North Korean pro-wrestling event.

item.title: SUV runs over boy, but then ...
item.description: Surveillance video shows a boy being hit by an SUV in front of his home. CNN's Andrew Stevens has more.

item.title: Is 'immortal' jellyfish key to life?
item.description: In Japan, scientists investigate whether a mysterious jellyfish could help prevent the aging process.

item.title: Panda faked pregnancy for buns
item.description: A giant panda slated to be the star of the first-ever live broadcast of the birth of panda cubs has lost the role -- after it was discovered the bear is not pregnant after all, Chinese state media reported.

item.title: ISIS 'selling Yazidi women' as slaves
item.description: U.S. forces drop aid for surrounded Iraqi town and carry out airstrikes on ISIS targets to protect against "imminent massacre", Pentagon says.

item.title: Libyans 'paying price' for Mideast divide
item.description: A New York Times article has reported that the United Arab Emirates and Egypt have launched airstrikes in Libya against militias, without coordinating with their ally, the United States of America.

item.title: She's planning for space catastrophe
item.description: Nelly Ben Hayoun is on a mission: to convince the world of the dangers posed by asteroid strikes.

item.title: 19 truly special vacations
item.description: Scrap all those other bucket lists and start saving.

item.title: Can Erdogan save Turkey's economy?
item.description: Recep Tayyip Erdogan was officially sworn in as Turkey's new president Thursday after comfortably winning the country's first direct vote to decide its head of state earlier this month. The appointment could see the 60-year-old former semi-professional football player remain at the top of Turkish politics for at least another decade.

item.title: Drone's eye view of earthquake damage
item.description: See a drone's eye view of the aftermath of the 6.0 Napa earthquake.

item.title: Reclining seats debate rages on
item.description: A squabble over a device that limits how far a seat can recline has brought inflight etiquette into the spotlight again.

item.title: China's dismal flight record firsthand
item.description: It was 2 a.m. on a stormy summer morning.

item.title: Floating bikes and levitating games?
item.description: Are we looking at a future where appliances float free through levitation?

item.title: Is this the fittest man on Earth?
item.description: Picture it: A four-day competition, with two to four workouts a day that consist of running, swimming, muscle-ups, 345-pound squat cleans, handstand push-ups, rope climbs, double unders, handstand walks, 245-pound overhead squats and more, against 43 of the most in-shape competitors you know, all with the title of Fittest on Earth on the line.

item.title: The business of hostage negotiations
item.description: In the delicate business of hostage negotiation, the focus is on the lives, not money. CNN's Karl Penhaul reports.

item.title: The man who hunted bin Laden, Saddam
item.description: On Thursday in Tampa, U.S. Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel presided over a change of command ceremony during which Adm. William "Bill" McRaven handed over the reins of Special Operations Command to his successor, Gen. Joseph Votel.

item.title: Paul McCartney urges UK to be united
item.description: Beatles star Paul McCartney became the latest high profile figure to sign a letter calling on Scottish voters to choose to remain part of the United Kingdom in a vote on independence next month.

item.title: A view to die for: Dubai time-lapse
item.description: Take a one-minute escape into the heart of Dubai.

item.title: Ouch! Would you get stun-gunned for art?
item.description: This is what "ouch" looks like. CNN's Jeanne Moos reports on stunning portraits taken while getting stun-gunned.

item.title: How one man made football pay
item.description: When the world's most notorious match fixer praises your refereeing, it's time to show yourself a red card.

item.title: 'Peanut butter killed my mother'
item.description: It was in a bland, windowless third-floor courtroom here that Jeff Almer first locked eyes with the man he holds responsible for his mother's death.

item.title: Does Britain have a jihadi problem?
item.description: James Foley's murder sparks fears the U.S.'s closest ally is an incubator for extremism.

item.title: Muslims fear witch-hunt
item.description: Worshipers fear that all Muslims could be targeted in the hunt for British jihadis linked to ISIS.

item.title: Does UK have a jihadi problem?
item.description: "Any attempt by you, Obama, to deny the Muslims their rights of living in safety under the Islamic caliphate will result in the bloodshed of your people" may have been the last words James Foley ever heard.

item.title: U.S. men detained in N. Korea speak
item.description: Three Americans -- Kenneth Bae, Matthew Todd Miller and Jeffrey Edward Fowle -- detained in North Korea spoke out about their conditions in an interview with CNN's Will Ripley.

item.title: Ukrainian troops demoralized, tired
item.description: Ukrainian troops appear dejected and tell a CNN crew of the horrors they've endured.

item.title: What can the West do about Vladimir Putin?
item.description: Russia's tactics in Ukraine are difficult to pin down: The Kremlin categorically denies Russian troops are fighting alongside rebels there, or that the sophisticated weaponry being used against Ukrainian government forces is supplied by Moscow.

item.title: Ukraine war fears
item.description: A United States lawmaker is calling for the arming of Ukrainian forces engaged in fighting Russian troops along the nations' eastern border with Russia.

item.title: Hong Kong democracy
item.description: It's a decision thousands of protesters feared.

item.title: Pakistan protests
item.description: Pakistani protesters flooded onto Constitution Avenue in Islamabad for another day of demonstrations Sunday, demanding a solution to the growing political crisis wracking the country.

item.title: North Korea
item.description: The crowd cheers as the stars make their way to the ring for first pro-wrestling bout North Korea has seen in almost 20 years.

item.title: Cancer boy found
item.description: The parents who pulled their cancer-stricken son from a British hospital and spurred an international search for the boy have been ordered to appear Monday in a court in Spain, where they were arrested, police said.

item.title: Lesotho
item.description: After an apparent attempted military coup on Saturday, the people of the African nation of Lesotho are doing their best to return to every day life.

item.title: Stun-gunned for art?
item.description: This is what "ouch" looks like. CNN's Jeanne Moos reports on stunning portraits taken while getting stun-gunned.

item.title: Escobar's hitman freed
item.description: John Jairo Velasquez, who was drug lord Pablo Escobar's hit man, has been released from prison. CNN's Rafael Romo reports.

item.title: Who owns these cars?
item.description: In what has become a summer tradition, wealthy Arabs travel to London with their expensive supercars.

item.title: Are these bright lights a UFO?
item.description: Video and pictures posted online of bright lights over the skies of Houston have many wondering if they saw a UFO.

item.title: Finding the perfect burger
item.description: American burger joints have sprung up all over London, but how to know which ones are best? Jim Boulden investigates.

item.title: Japan's cross-dressing icon
item.description: A cross-dressing Japanese man is challenging social norms, encouraging young people to be themselves.

item.title: Tattoo art business boom
item.description: Don't call them parlors, they are tattoo art studios and are no longer in decline. CNN's Jim Boulden reports.

item.title: Put a bird on it
item.description: Who among us hasn't fantasized about flying like a bird? We've created hot air balloons, planes and spacecraft to replicate what birds can already do naturally.

item.title: The brightest supermoon
item.description: The second installment of this summer's season of supermoons is happening Sunday.

item.title: 10 things we didn't know about lighthouses
item.description: In honor of National Lighthouse Day, we invited you to share your best lighthouse photos with CNN iReport. As dozens of images started pouring in, we were reminded of a near-universal fact: People love lighthouses. The beacons of light are popular travel destinations across the world.

item.title: Gaza crisis brings 9/11 flashbacks
item.description: I am an American, and I love my country, but I also love my heritage.

item.title: Bomb blasts and wedding bells
item.description: She has been dreaming about this day for as long as I can remember.

item.title: Stop spy flights, China warns the U.S.
item.description: China has warned the United States to end its military surveillance flights near Chinese territory, rejecting claims by Washington that a Chinese fighter jet made several "dangerous" and "unprofessional" passes at a U.S. Navy plane last week.

item.title: Xi Jinping echoes 'paramount leader'
item.description: The 110th birthday of former Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping was celebrated on August 22 with an exhibition, a television biopic, and a series of national events. The "paramount leader" ruled for more than a decade, kick-starting China's market economic reform.

item.title: What's wrong with winning?
item.description: Off-camera, I'm getting parenting advice from China's first athlete to win gold in any sport at the Winter Olympics.

item.title: China executes attack 'masterminds'
item.description: China has executed eight people convicted of terrorism, including three for their roles in an attack in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in October, the state-run Xinhua news agency reported, citing local authorities.

item.title: Keeping traditions alive
item.description: With more than 6,000 years of history, China's ancient capital of Nanjing has been the birthplace of many of the country's most intriguing traditional arts.

item.title: China slams 'aggressive jet' claim
item.description: A Chinese fighter jet made several "dangerous" and "unprofessional" passes at a U.S. Navy plane this week -- coming as close as 20 feet at one point -- in what the White House called a "deeply concerning provocation."

item.title: Parched residents dig wells
item.description: At first glance, it seems like a lot of roadside construction is taking place in this residential neighborhood west of Beijing's Tsinghua University.

item.title: Sino-theology and the pope
item.description: Detentions, the kidnapping of bishops, tearing down churches -- these are the actions against Christians China has been guilty of.

item.title: World's first panda triplets
item.description: Very few pandas are born each year, but even fewer of the fragile cubs stay alive.

item.title: Japan's defense plans rile China
item.description: Japan's new defense white paper has done little to mend fences with Beijing, with the Chinese government complaining that its Asian neighbor is using the "China threat" to justify a bigger defense budget.

item.title: Did couple steal state secrets?
item.description: A Canadian couple living in a city close to China's border with North Korea are under investigation for the suspected theft of state secrets, state media said Tuesday.
